LymphTree.title: Start
LymphTree.content:
Aim of the present algorithm: to guide the physician to the correct clinical approach to lymphoadenopathies (LAP).

Rationale: the diagnostic reasoning is based on anamnestic information and physical findings: their accurate exploitation – under the guidance of a wide clinical knowledge and bed-side experience – can make the diagnostic path more direct, short and, ultimatively, cheap.

The first required assessments for the use of the present application are a few basic data regarding the LAP:


  1. anatomical site of the swelling

  2. findings recorded through the physical examination of the patient (to choose the most appropriate semeiologic category of the patient under study, see Table 1)

  3. a number of potentially discriminant anamnestic or concomitant clinical characteristics



Related to the anatomical site an important acquisition is related to the spread of the LAP:

  • is it localized to a single lymph node or to a group of neighbouring lymph nodes, or to a number of lymph nodes confined to a single region (L)?

  • or is the LAP systemic, i.e., generalized (G)?
LymphTree.question: General Information - A diagnostical flow-chart for lymphoadenopathies

LymphTree.title: Table 1
LymphTree.content:
A Stable result of preceding inflammations.
Lymph node not much swelled, with increased consistence, indolent , not hurting at palpation, mobile with respect to deep and superficial tissues; it is generally found by the patient during shaving or washing. It represents the stable outcome of past, often repeated, inflammations.

B Inflammatory lymph node.
Consistence is reduced, nodules are rather tender and elastic, moderately or heavily aching, with pain increasing at palpation; the skin covering and surrounding the nodule is reddish, sometimes a few, contiguous, inflammatory lymph nodes during their growth tend to agglomerate. Often a lymphangitic stripe connets the swollen node to the site of infection. Fluctuation is rarely possible.

C Neoplastic lymph node.
Consistency is decisely increased, more heavily in case of involvement by carcinomas or sarcomas than by lymphomas, but differences are too slight for a clear discrimination; they are poorly to not aching at all, independent of palpation, mobility is reduced, especially over deep tissues, surface of the swelling mass is lumpy as the result of a coalescence of multiple nodes ; rarely, nowadays, the skin over the node ulcerates.
LymphTree.question: Physical Categories

LymphTree.title: Note
LymphTree.content:
Of course, we must consider the possibility that what at any given moment appears to be a localized LAP is going on to become generalized after a few days, so that one or more physical examinations are necessary after variable time.

Most of the relationships pointed out are probabilistic, and not deterministic. A few others are proposed for completeness of investigation, serving as a mere reminder to the physician about some rare conditions.

The wide availability of soft tissue ultrasonographic scan (US) often allows an early, suitable and accurate verification of the palpatory findings, in particular related to the discrimination between inflammatory or neoplastic involvement.

Thus, the discriminating ultrasonographic aspects are described here (see Table 2), since they have to be considered as a frequent, easy and useful complement of the clinical examination.


Important note
Type-A lymph nodes and type C, generalized lymph nodes will not be considered in the present flow-chart: the first must undergo new physical and ultrasonographic controls within the next 2-5 weeks; the second needs a surgical biopsy to reach the diagnosis as soon as possible

LymphTree.title: Table 2
LymphTree.content:
Type B LAP (inflammatory)


  • the swollen lymph node maintains an oval shape
  • the normal rate between major and minor axis is saved (≥ 2)
  • vascular hilum is recognizable,
  • the vascular-fatty stria is visible, set along the major axis
  • cortex is slightly hypoecogenic.




Type C LAP (neoplastic)

  • globular shape,
  • vascular hilum and vascular-fatty stria not recognizable,
  • diffuse hyperechogenicity.
LymphTree.question: Ultrasonographic Findings

LymphTree.title: Three steps for the start of investigation
LymphTree.content:
First, you must choose the grade of clinical spread reached by the LAP under evaluation (localized [L] or generalized [G]?)

Second, you have to choose the semeiologic cathegory, to which the LAP under examination belongs: B or C (see Tab. 1) The aid of an ultrasonographic scan whould be very helpful in this assessment. (see Tab. 2); with this step you realize if you are searching for a tumor rather than an infectious or an inflammatory disease).

Third, the combined information from step 1 and 2 will determine the starting point of your investigation along the flow chart (see Tab. 3). You must very carefully examine each step of the flow-chart (y = yes; n= no), interpreting the offered information as suggestions or clues with higher probability, not as an absolute statements.
Remember: the correctness of the clinical procedures – not of the diagnosis –is guaranted by this flow-chart


At the bottom of every page you will find essential information on the laboratory and instrumental tests needed to confirm the diagnosis (D), and on the principal drugs utilized in the therapy of the diagnosed ill (T).
LymphTree.question: Three Steps:

LymphTree.title: Table 3
LymphTree.content:
LOCALIZED (L)
Localized to a single lymph node or to a group of neighbouring lymph nodes or to lymph nodes confined to one single anatomic region.



GENERALIZED (G)
Involvement is systemic or at least
involves lymph nodes of more than one single anatomic region

LymphTree.title: Category C - Localized LAP
LymphTree.content:
The anatomical areas whose lymph is drained through the swollen lymph nodes under examination – with characteristics 'C'– must be carefully evaluated, taking into account the specific distribution of the regional lymphatic vessels


Occipital / retrocervical
Scalp, outer ear, skin of the neck


Cervical
Orbital tissues, middle ear, nose, skin of face and neck, paranasal sinuses, salivary glands, nasopharinx, tonsils, hyopharynx, larynx, thyroid, upper esophagus


Supraclavear, Mediastinal Retroperitoneal
Bronchi, pleura, breasts, esophagus, stomach pancreas, kidneys, colon, internal genitals, skin of the whole trunk


Axillary
Breasts, bronchi, skin of the arm and upper trunk


Inguinal
External genitals, rectum, anus, skin of legs and perineum

LymphTree.title: African Triponosomias
LymphTree.content:
African Tripanosomiasis 1 (Winterbottom's disease & homonimous sign) [m-b; m-l; m-lnb → Piringer Kuchinka's adenoitis]

1To be distinguished from American Trypanosomiasis (Winterbottom sign: bulky occipital LAP)

Vector: hematophagous flies

Diagnosis: m-t; m-b; m-lnb → Piringer Kucionka’s adenitis

Therapy: suramin, pentammidine, melaarsoprol

LymphTree.title: Diagnosis not reached
LymphTree.content: Consider strict clinical follow-up and/or m-lnB and/or application  of the cervical steps to occipital LAP

LymphTree.question: Sudden rise of a nodule or swelling of a pre-existing minor nodule ?
LAP subauricular or under jaw angle or before s.c.m. muscle ? (A)
LAP on the midline from hyoid bone and thyroid? (B)

LymphTree.title: Branchial cyst from the II (A) or III-IV (B) embryological arches. Surgery
American Tripanosomiasis - early phase (Romaña’s Syndrome of Chagas’ disease)

LymphTree.question: Exanthem + bright red coating of tongue ?
Hepatomegaly? Systemic spread of LAP? Splenomegaly ?
Is exudate spreading outside the tonsils ?

LymphTree.title: Infection by: Adenovirus, Influenza virus, Parainfluenza virus

LymphTree.question: Chest RX result?
LymphTree.answer1: Negative + LAP of high cervical sites
LymphTree.answer2: Positive + LAP of low cervical sites

LymphTree.title: Diagnosis not reached
LymphTree.content:
Retrace the path: and consider every step again as accurate as possible.
Explore the possibility of a neoplastic (C) LAP.
Evaluate the patient again and thoroughly after a few days

LymphTree.question: Contacts with cats? Upper limb skin lesions?
Contact with flowers, musk, ornamental plants? Miscellaneous cutaneous injuries, nodules, pustules?
Immigration from areas with endemic leprosy ?
Aching LAP in young woman’s axilla ?

LymphTree.title: Examine breast: Mastitis; Elder woman’s telitis; Post traumatic steatonecrosis; Mammary thrombophlebitis; Neoplasia
Herpes genitalis; Chancroid; Lymphogranuloma venereum; Gonorrhea; Primary Siphilis

LymphTree.question: Stay in, or immigration from, tropical countries ?
Contact with animals - including pets - parasitized by fleas ?
Coming from areasa of sporadic or endemic pestis ?
Coming from areasb of sporadic or endemic leprosy ?

LymphTree.title: Hilar Mediastinal
LymphTree.question: Hilar LAP ± pulmonary infiltrate ± pleural effusion ?
Stay or immigration from Northern and Central America ?
Contact with pigeons or their escrements ?
s T-ly > 20% ? T4/T8 > 4 in c-bal ? sACE elevated ?
Significant skin tests ? Sputum, gastrolusis and feces with alcohol and acid resistant bacilli ?

LymphTree.title: Diagnosis not reached
LymphTree.content: Consider alternative hypothesis, possibly arising from thoracic TC and m-bw.

LymphTree.question: Hilar calcific LAP, exposure to silica, reticular infiltrates ?

LymphTree.title: West Nilo Fever; Ebola and Marburg virus Infections; Leptospirosis

LymphTree.question: Anular erythema Migrans ? Rural Contacts ? Lices ? Tick ?
Rush as above without vesicles, Involving also mucosae ?
Infant with small papules, necrotic pustules & hepato-splenomegaly ?
Transient erythema, confined to the abdomen ?
Itchy, linear erythema, at the side of the palm and/or the sole, after therapies with serum, hydantoin, carbamazepine, phenylbutazone, para-minosalicylic acid ?

LymphTree.title: Hypothyroidism under infectious diseases (thiphoid fever, brucellosis, Chagas’ disease, etc.)

LymphTree.question: Increased urinary red cells, albumin and cylinders ? AST< (n.v. x 5) ?

LymphTree.title: Hemolytic anemias; hepatic, infectious, autoimmune diseases; lymphomas

LymphTree.question: Adolescent or adult with high acid phosphases ?
Profuse sweats, irregular fever, generalized pain ?

LymphTree.title: MGUS; Myeloma; Plasma cell leukemia; Macroglobulinemia; Amyloidosis; Heavy chain disease; LLC, CMMoL; Lymphomas; Cryoglobulinemia; LES

LymphTree.question: Urinary sediment with abnormal number of erythrocytes and/ /or cylinders ?

LymphTree.title: Polyarteritis nodosa; Chickenpox (varicella); Systemic sclerosis; Scarlet fever; Dermatomyositis; Tuberculosis; Rheumatoid arthritis; Leptospirosis; Syphilis; Plague; Systemic lupus erythematosus

LymphTree.question: Immature cells, Increased basophils and/or platelet ?

LymphTree.title: HCL; Splenic lymphoma with hairy Cells

LymphTree.question: Circulating large lymphocytes with serpentine nuclei ?
Eating raw meat ? Contact with cats ?

LymphTree.title: CML, EL, ALL, ANLL; Lymphomas; Amyloidosis; Gaucher’s disease; Niemann-Pick dis.; Myelophtisis
CML; Polyarteritis nodosa; Dermatomyositis; Hodgkin’s lymphoma; Systemic Lupus
CLL; Macroglobulinemia; Low-grade lymphomas; HCL; Some terminal lymphomas

LymphTree.question: Arthralgias & myalgias with or without light splenomegaly?

Chronic Fatigue Syndrome; Still’s disease; Juvenile R A; Polyarteritis nodosa; Systemic sclerosis
